results.title: Disco
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Growing Up”.
This film considers social and sexual expectations and attitudes of teenagers attending a disco. Their perceptions of male and female roles, the similarities and differences are portrayed through their behaviour, conversation and dress. Cinematography by Mike Edols.

results.title: Brad
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Growing Up”.
Brad identifies himself as a homosexual. The film examines his reactions to homosexuality and the importance of relationships with other males. His mother expresses her feelings about Brad’s sexuality; he is shown in his employment and enjoying himself socially.

results.title: Groupthink
results.creator_credit: Steven Katten, Communication Research Materials Production and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Group Dynamics”.
Analyses the dynamics of group decision-making and explores the processes which inhibit creativity and foster “groupthink”.

results.title: Crime and the criminal
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great Themes of Literature”.
Edited from Richard Brooks’ film ‘In Cold Blood’, an adaptation of Truman Capote’s novel which explores the inner life of a criminal. A sensitive probe into the factors that may have created the criminal, considering how is different from the rest of society and questions the use of the death penalty.

results.title: Power and corruption
results.creator_credit: Roman Polanski and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great Themes of Literature”.
This specially edited version of Polanski’s “Macbeth” focuses on the dramatic chain of events precipitated by Macbeth’s killing of Duncan, his king. One of the results of the sinister murder is that Macbeth is crowned King of Scotland in an impressive ceremony at Scone. The other fruits of his action, however, are bitter, for Macbeth has to learn that power illegally gained corrupts no one so much as him who gets it.

results.title: Man and woman
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great Themes of Literature”.
This film, edited from Zeffirelli’s lusty version of Shakespeare’s “Taming of the Shrew”, unfurls with great fun a Renaissance version of the spectacle known as ‘the battle of the sexes’. Stars Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor. As the commentator points out the dramatising violent conflict between men and women in search of love is one way that world literature has dealt with the relationship between the sexes.

results.title: Heroes and cowards
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great Themes of Literature”.
This film is specially edited from the Richard Brooks film “Lord Jim”, based on the novel by Joseph Conrad. Discusses the story of a young man whose heroic ideals for himself are tested by the harsh challenge and demands of reality. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Conscience in conflict
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great Themes of Literature”.
At the opening of this edited version of the film ‘Man for all Seasons’, based on Robert Bolt’s play, Sir Thomas More is about to be executed. He has chosen to die rather than compromise his religious beliefs, the principles which he feels constitute his very identity. He is making an existential stand. The commentator for the series, Orson Welles, describes Sir Thomas More’s dilemma. King Henry VIII has decided to divorce Catherine of Aragon and marry Anne Boleyn. The King wants England’s nobility to support his decision by endorsing the Act of Supremacy. Next to the King, Sir Thomas More is the most powerful man in England and his approval is of the utmost importance. However, herein lies the conflict - More cannot condone either the King’s divorce or his usurpation of the Church’s authority. He chooses silence as a middle course. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Columbia Pictures and Learning Corporation of America
